I'm working with ModellingToolkit and DiffEqOperators to solve a set of PDEs, and I wanted to test out a simpler problem before I jumped into my problem. I followed the <http://diffeqoperators.sciml.ai/stable/examples/#Heat-equation|heat equation example> and that worked, so I next wanted to try 1D linear advection with periodic boundary conditions, but I'm having some issues with the boundary conditions:

```@parameters t x
@variables u(..)
@derivatives Dt'~t
@derivatives Dx'~x

a = 1
advection_eq = Dt(u(t, x)) ~ -a * Dx(u(t, x))
advection_bcs = [
	u(0, x) ~ sinpi(x),
	PeriodicBC(Float64)
]
domains = [
	t ∈ IntervalDomain(0.0, 1.0),
	x ∈ IntervalDomain(0.0, 1.0)
]
advection_pdesys = PDESystem(advection_eq, advection_bcs, domains, [t, x], [u])
advection_dx = 0.01
advection_order = 2
advection_discretization = MOLFiniteDifference(advection_dx, advection_order)
advection_prob = ModelingToolkit.discretize(advection_pdesys, advection_discretization)
advection_sol = solve(advection_prob, Tsit5(), saveat = 0.1)```
This errors because `type PeriodicBC has no field lhs` . What is the indended way to use the periodic boundary condition?

I've tried `u(t, 0) ~ u(t, 1)`  but that gives me an undefined reference error

messages.text:
Hi! I tried to solve differential equations with a bunch of randomly generated initial values and parameters.
Chris Rackauckas said using StaticArrays could speed up calculation in DifferentialEquation.jl. So I tried to generate StaticArrays in each iteration and for each population. Since those calculations are independent, so I tried to use multithreads to accelerate. However, StaticArrays leads to wrong answers. It will mix up when using Threads. So How can I use StaticArrays to faster solve ODE with parallel computing?
I read his tutorial about parallelism (<https://mitmath.github.io/18337/lecture5/parallelism_overview.html>) and tried to generate StaticArray for each thread like this
`u = Vector{typeof(@SVector([1.0,0.0,0.0]))}(undef,1000)`
But for each iteration, the StaticArray needs to be regenerated randomly for initial values, since SVector is immutable, so I could not use it. So is there a way to use StaticArrays to speed up solving ODE with parallel computing?

elements.text:
Hi! I tried to solve differential equations with a bunch of randomly generated initial values and parameters.
Chris Rackauckas said using StaticArrays could speed up calculation in DifferentialEquation.jl. So I tried to generate StaticArrays in each iteration and for each population. Since those calculations are independent, so I tried to use multithreads to accelerate. However, StaticArrays leads to wrong answers. It will mix up when using Threads. So How can I use StaticArrays to faster solve ODE with parallel computing?
I read his tutorial about parallelism (
) and tried to generate StaticArray for each thread like this

But for each iteration, the StaticArray needs to be regenerated randomly for initial values, since SVector is immutable, so I could not use it. So is there a way to use StaticArrays to speed up solving ODE with parallel computing?

the history segment
what do you mean by that?

messages.text: the history function?
one of the 3 terms that make up the history function?

elements.text: one of the 3 terms that make up the history function?

messages.text: I want to know the state. In ODE, the state space is the state space of u0 and you find a periodic orbit when u0 = Flow(u0, T). In DDE, the state space in infinite dim, in effect given by history segments C([0, \tau], R) where tau is the constant delay. I need to discretise this. Hence, how do you encode the history segment?

elements.text: I want to know the state. In ODE, the state space is the state space of u0 and you find a periodic orbit when u0 = Flow(u0, T). In DDE, the state space in infinite dim, in effect given by history segments C([0, \tau], R) where tau is the constant delay. I need to discretise this. Hence, how do you encode the history segment?

just a history function
It is a function in DelayDiffEq, as Chris says

elements.text: It is a function in DelayDiffEq, as Chris says

messages.text: Nice to hear that you had a look! The runtime is not so great yet, but mostly due more to implementation details than actual algorithmic complexity I believe. I'm still actively working on making it faster so that it hopefully gets more comparable to some stiff solvers of OrdinaryDiffEq. The run against DP5 is not winnable though since there are some matrix multiplications we just can't get rid of, but currently I really think that it's more interesting to compare the EKF1 to other stiff solvers than to try to compete with RK.

elements.text: Nice to hear that you had a look! The runtime is not so great yet, but mostly due more to implementation details than actual algorithmic complexity I believe. I'm still actively working on making it faster so that it hopefully gets more comparable to some stiff solvers of OrdinaryDiffEq. The run against DP5 is not winnable though since there are some matrix multiplications we just can't get rid of, but currently I really think that it's more interesting to compare the EKF1 to other stiff solvers than to try to compete with RK.

messages.text: But I hope to make a meaningful work-precision diagram with runtimes soon :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: But I hope to make a meaningful work-precision diagram with runtimes soon

messages.text: I'm looking to solve an advection-type PDE using `DiffEqOperators` , ideally in 2D (spatially). While it may be counter productive, I am looking to not use method of lines in the solution. Would this be a valid use of `DiffEqOperators`? The docs/examples seem to be spread out over DEO, MTK, and DifferentialEquations. Using MTK would be great, as I do not deal with PDEs much, but since I am looking for a concrete-tized representation of the problem it appears that working directly in DEO would be best? Any insights would be appreciated!

elements.text: I'm looking to solve an advection-type PDE using
, ideally in 2D (spatially). While it may be counter productive, I am looking to not use method of lines in the solution. Would this be a valid use of

? The docs/examples seem to be spread out over DEO, MTK, and DifferentialEquations. Using MTK would be great, as I do not deal with PDEs much, but since I am looking for a concrete-tized representation of the problem it appears that working directly in DEO would be best? Any insights would be appreciated!

messages.text: Good morning folks. I am looking at a system of discrete stochastic difference equations, to look at hiring activity in an organization. Most hiring happens in a clumpy fashion and so it is really not a continuous process. In it simplest formulation, model is essentially a birth-death process where new individuals join each month and current individuals retire each month--though usually both activities happen in the first week of each month. Now can I use the `SDEProblem` in DifferentialEquations.jl to run these simulations, but just set `dt` to a larger increment--such as a monthly increment? Also, would I need to set the `saveat` parameter to something like a monthly increment as well? I will have to subsequently estimate hiring and retirement rates using the model and some data.

elements.text: Good morning folks. I am looking at a system of discrete stochastic difference equations, to look at hiring activity in an organization. Most hiring happens in a clumpy fashion and so it is really not a continuous process. In it simplest formulation, model is essentially a birth-death process where new individuals join each month and current individuals retire each month--though usually both activities happen in the first week of each month. Now can I use the

to a larger increment--such as a monthly increment? Also, would I need to set the `saveat` parameter to something like a monthly increment as well? I will have to subsequently estimate hiring and retirement rates using the model and some data.

messages.text: I've solved a similar problem and I think the best thing to do, like mentioned above, is to interpolate `f` to be continuous on that grid, so you can just evaluate it at whatever coordinate you need without a lookup

messages.text: Hi there, I was running into some instabilities for more extreme values of initial conditions, and I was planning on just ignoring them--depending on integrator to abort with `:DtLessThanMin`. I ran into an issue though where some cases caused the adaptive time stepper to loop over the same six values of `t` over and over without aborting. Is there some way I can avoid this?

<@U69BL50BF> In your UDE paper, you formulate the ML function U as U(x,t) where x is the current state. Do you see any reason why this couldn't also include additional, external data, i.e. U(x,t;y) where y is either time invariant or a function of time, like series data?

messages.text:
I have an SDE on a Lie group, written
```dx = L dw
g(t + dt) = g(t) \circ \exp(\sum_{i=1}^d E_i dx_i)
g(0) = e```
where `x` is in the Lie algebra, `\exp` is the group exponential map, `E_i` is some orthogonal basis in the Lie algebra, `d` is the dimension, `\circ` is group composition,  `e` is the identity element, and `dw` is a wiener process. Can this SDE be solved with the DifferentialEquations ecosystem? I have a custom Euler-Maruyama solver right now but would like to generalize.

elements.text: I have an SDE on a Lie group, written

dx = L dw
g(t + dt) = g(t) \circ \exp(\sum_{i=1}^d E_i dx_i)
g(0) = e
is some orthogonal basis in the Lie algebra,
is a wiener process. Can this SDE be solved with the DifferentialEquations ecosystem? I have a custom Euler-Maruyama solver right now but would like to generalize.

messages.text: there are exponential integrators for SDEs

elements.text: there are exponential integrators for SDEs

messages.text: we haven't implemented them yet :shrug:

<@U69BL50BF> Have you or your colleagues thought about the relationship between (and apparent advantages of) UDEs and traditional data assimilation techniques, i.e. via Kalman filters or something similar? Of course UDEs are far more powerful and expressive, but this might be a useful comparison to make in order to convince scientists/practitioners in the modeling world who might be skeptical of directly modifying their numerical models.

elements.text: Have you or your colleagues thought about the relationship between (and apparent advantages of) UDEs and traditional data assimilation techniques, i.e. via Kalman filters or something similar? Of course UDEs are far more powerful and expressive, but this might be a useful comparison to make in order to convince scientists/practitioners in the modeling world who might be skeptical of directly modifying their numerical models.

messages.text: Should calculating the determinant of a (small, real) matrix using MTK be something that works for arbitrary matrices? Or should it fall to the user to check that the function MTK generates does not involve division by zero for their particular matrix?

messages.text:
We already have it
```julia> using ModelingToolkit, LinearAlgebra

julia> @variables A[1:4, 1:4];

julia> det(A)
((((1 * A₁ˏ₁) * (A₂ˏ₂ - ((A₂ˏ₁ / A₁ˏ₁) * A₁ˏ₂))) * ((A₃ˏ₃ - ((A₃ˏ₁ / A₁ˏ₁) * A₁ˏ₃)) - (((A₃ˏ₂ - ((A₃ˏ₁ / A₁ˏ₁) * A₁ˏ₂)) / (A₂ˏ₂ - ((A₂ˏ₁ / A₁ˏ₁) * A₁ˏ₂))) * (A₂ˏ₃ - ((A₂ˏ₁ / A₁ˏ₁) * A₁ˏ₃))))) * (((A₄ˏ₄ - ((A₄ˏ₁ / A₁ˏ₁) * A₁ˏ₄)) - (((A₄ˏ₂ - ((A₄ˏ₁ / A₁ˏ₁) * A₁ˏ₂)) / (A₂ˏ₂ - ((A₂ˏ₁ / A₁ˏ₁) * A₁ˏ₂))) * (A₂ˏ₄ - ((A₂ˏ₁ / A₁ˏ₁) * A₁ˏ₄)))) - ((((A₄ˏ₃ - ((A₄ˏ₁ / A₁ˏ₁) * A₁ˏ₃)) - (((A₄ˏ₂ - ((A₄ˏ₁ / A₁ˏ₁) * A₁ˏ₂)) / (A₂ˏ₂ - ((A₂ˏ₁ / A₁ˏ₁) * A₁ˏ₂))) * (A₂ˏ₃ - ((A₂ˏ₁ / A₁ˏ₁) * A₁ˏ₃)))) / ((A₃ˏ₃ - ((A₃ˏ₁ / A₁ˏ₁) * A₁ˏ₃)) - (((A₃ˏ₂ - ((A₃ˏ₁ / A₁ˏ₁) * A₁ˏ₂)) / (A₂ˏ₂ - ((A₂ˏ₁ / A₁ˏ₁) * A₁ˏ₂))) * (A₂ˏ₃ - ((A₂ˏ₁ / A₁ˏ₁) * A₁ˏ₃))))) * ((A₃ˏ₄ - ((A₃ˏ₁ / A₁ˏ₁) * A₁ˏ₄)) - (((A₃ˏ₂ - ((A₃ˏ₁ / A₁ˏ₁) * A₁ˏ₂)) / (A₂ˏ₂ - ((A₂ˏ₁ / A₁ˏ₁) * A₁ˏ₂))) * (A₂ˏ₄ - ((A₂ˏ₁ / A₁ˏ₁) * A₁ˏ₄))))))) * 1```

messages.text: `det` just uses LU

Also, since my LU PR, we have pretty nice capabilities like
```julia> simplify.(A \ A[:, 1])
4-element Vector{Num}:
 1
 0
 0
 0```

elements.text: Also, since my LU PR, we have pretty nice capabilities like

messages.text:
What I meant, is that the divisions in your expression can cause `NaN` for certain matrices.
```using ModelingToolkit
using LinearAlgebra
@variables X[1:2,1:2]

d = det(X);
_det = eval(build_function(d,X))

X_test1 = [1.0 0.0; 0.0 1.0]
det(X_test1)
_det(X_test1)

X_test2 = zeros(2,2)
det(X_test2)
_det(X_test2)

X_test3 = [0.0 1.0; 1.0 0.0]
det(X_test3)
_det(X_test3)```
I personally understand why tracing  `det` and `lu` causes this, but am just wondering if a user should expect this behavior?

elements.text: What I meant, is that the divisions in your expression can cause

using ModelingToolkit
using LinearAlgebra
@variables X[1:2,1:2]

d = det(X);
_det = eval(build_function(d,X))

X_test1 = [1.0 0.0; 0.0 1.0]
det(X_test1)
_det(X_test1)

X_test2 = zeros(2,2)
det(X_test2)
_det(X_test2)

X_test3 = [0.0 1.0; 1.0 0.0]
det(X_test3)
_det(X_test3)
causes this, but am just wondering if a user should expect this behavior?

messages.text: That’s not solvable. There’s no value information in symbols

elements.text: That’s not solvable. There’s no value information in symbols

messages.text: If you want O(N^3) computation time of det instead of O(N!) you need value information.

elements.text: If you want O(N^3) computation time of det instead of O(N!) you need value information.

messages.text: There are better ways for evaluating det for small matrices than just unroll the expression. You can specialize on size and use StaticArrays.

elements.text: There are better ways for evaluating det for small matrices than just unroll the expression. You can specialize on size and use StaticArrays.

messages.text: I understand it is not solvable in an efficient way, but I just found it a bit disconcerting `det` can silently evaluate to `NaN` . (And also I have weird use cases where I need the unrolled expression)

elements.text: I understand it is not solvable in an efficient way, but I just found it a bit disconcerting
. (And also I have weird use cases where I need the unrolled expression)

messages.text:
Maybe we could have
```det(A; cofactor=true) ...```
by default.
det by cofactor expansion won’t give NaN, but that’s probably not usable for anything larger than 4 x 4

elements.text: det by cofactor expansion won’t give NaN, but that’s probably not usable for anything larger than 4 x 4
